thread.title: Why is the White House tech officer chasing down a historical document?
thread.title_full: Why is the White House tech officer chasing down a historical document? - The Washington Post

author: John Woodrow Cox
title: Why is the White House tech officer chasing down a historical document?
text:
White House Chief Technology Officer Megan Smith (L) speaks at an Oct. 13 event, with Xerox chairman and chief executive Ursula Burns. (Paul Morigi/Getty Images for Fortune/Time Inc.) October 20 at 5:55 PM U.S. businesses’ records are being stolen every day. Many fear we are falling behind our adversaries. Hackers accessed 22 million files from the Office of Personnel Management . Yet White House Chief Technology Officer Megan Smith is hunting for Elizabeth Cady Stanton’s Declaration of Sentiments announced in 1848 [“ White House searches for suffragist manifesto ,” news, Oct. 16].
Here is the question: Why is the White House chief technology office using government time and resources concerning a 19th-century pre-technology historical event?
Michael J. McMorrow , Arlington
